awd_titl_txt: Plasmonic Metal Oxide Nanocrystals for Near-Field Coupling
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Delia Milliron of the University of Texas at Austin is developing doped metal oxide nanocrystals that can exchange energy with nearby molecules. These new nanoscale building blocks can be widely applied by chemists, materials scientists, and engineers to create functional materials and devices. Professor Milliron is mentoring graduate student, postdoctoral, and undergraduate researchers who are receiving a unique interdisciplinary educational experience, gaining expertise in topics including nanocrystal synthesis, spectroscopy, and simulation of light-matter interactions. Furthermore, Professor Milliron is developing a new educational module for use in pre-college outreach programs that introduce students to plasmonic phenomena and nanochemistry in general.

Nanocrystals under development in this project have resonant frequencies in the infrared spectral regime, different from the visible light resonance of classical metal nanoparticles such as gold or silver. Synthetic methods to tune dopant chemistry and dopant distribution are being developed to maximize the potential for near field coupling. Characterization of plasmon-vibrational coupling by Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy complements the synthetic developments underway and lays the foundation for directing energy flow to tune catalytic pathways and to develop advanced sensors and spectroscopic probes.

por.por_cntn:
Plasmonic metal oxide nanocrystals (NCs) efficiently confine light into nanoscopic volumes at the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) frequency. The concentration of electromagnetic energy strengthens the electric field at the NC surface, powering nearby processes. However, this "near-field enhancement" (NFE) only occurs around the LSPR frequency, so the nearby process must have a resonant frequency near that of the LSPR to encounter the enhanced field. This resonant interaction is called "coupling." Plasmonic metal oxide NCs have LSPR tunable throughout infrared frequencies, which overlaps with the majority of molecular vibrational frequencies. Our goals are (1) to develop plasmonic metal oxide NCs with high NFE and (2) to demonstrate these NCs can efficiently couple to molecular vibrations. To achieve these goals we first leveraged colloidal synthetic techniques to make NCs of various composition, size, and shape. Then we directly demonstrated LSPR-vibration coupling by detecting optical signatures indicative of coupled oscillators. Lastly, we probed the intra-NC electron concentration profile to understand how depletion of electrons near the NC surface hinders NFE and what can be done to mitigate it. 

NCs with reduced electron scattering and sharp facets are known to have high NFE. Through rational dopant selection we hypothesized cerium to be the ideal dopant to replace indium in In2O3 (Figure 1a). Indeed the LSPR response showed less electron scattering for cerium-doped indium oxide (Ce:In2O3) than the more common dopant, tin (Sn:In2O3). Moreover, we proved that fluorine can be used as a surface passivating agent to making large, cubic fluorine-doped indium oxide (F:In2O3) NCs (Figure 1b). With these two works alone, we significantly improved electric field enhancement throgh dopant and shape engineering, but we went further to make Nb:TiO2, ReO3, and even co-doped (F,Sn:In2O3), adding to our library of plasmonic metal oxide NCs and expanding the scope and impact for this material class.

We employed large, cubic, co-doped F,Sn:In2O3 to directly detect coupling signatures between LSPR and the carbon-hydrogen bonding mode. By depositing a film of NCs and oleic acid ligands, the optical response showed a Fano resonance, indicative of a broad (LSPR) mode coupling to a narrow (molecular vibration) mode. Through experiment and simulation we also learned that there is a strong size-dependence to this coupled interaction. Our deepened understanding means we can understand the nature of this nanoscale interaction, even from an ensemble spectrum.

Finally, upon electrochemical modulation of nanocrystal films, we learned that the intra-NC electron concentration profiles do not change uniformly - as is often assumed. This has strong implications for NFE and thus coupling potential. By modeling the optical response of electrochemically oxidized and reduced NCs, we showed that our NCs have an insulating shell, devoid of electrons. This shell forms an insulating barrier to the surroundings which strongly hinders coupling. Through a doping and size series, we found that larger, highly doped NCs are less affected by surface depletion and thus are the most promising candidates for coupling to molecular vibrations.

Over the time period of this project, we have constructed a library of diverse plasmonic metal oxide NCs, each with its own unique advantages to contribute. By choosing a system we knew to have high NFE (large, doped, and cubic) we were able to measure clear signatures of coupling between LSPR and molecular vibrational modes. Looking forward, we want to build upon this observation so that we can design systems the leverage LSPR-vibration coupling for enhanced sensing, hot electron transfer, or even resonant energy transduction in the infrared.
